bibl.note: This document is a letter dated the 7th of January, 1797 from governor John Sevier of Tennessee to members of Congress. In the Letter, Sevier informs the statesmen of supposed plundering of several wagons by Cherokee Indians while in route to the Cumberland plateau.

div.p: Since my last nothing of material moments excepting that Several waggons wagons on the road through the wilderness to Cumberland have been plundered by the indians supposed to be the cherokees , and some of them left without a horse, Supposed to be done by the Cherokees.

The agent to the cherokees has complained about Settlements being made as low down as the tennessee, on which Subject I to him replied, a copy of which is here inclosed for your information, should any thing or that head be brought sent forward to the department of war. It will elucidate in some measure the circumstances attending the matter, and you will take such measures in your wisdom will best promote the interest of this state I wish the line could be extended to the Tennessee.

It has for some time past been reported that one Indian was killed, and another wounded, on the waters of clinch; I hope the report is not true, and I am induced so to believe from this reason, that neither the indians nor agent have complained to me on the Occasion.

Our port was has several times been disappointed in meeting with and receiving in order the mail at abingdon, which neglect may prove very injurious to us. A letter from the department of
of war to the executive of this state, Dated 13 august last only arrived here on the 11th instant, brought by Mr Mister . John Deadrick from Cumberland, Another from same department dated 29 September came by our port a few days before. How these irregularities happen I am at a loss to know. It is not the first time my letters Directed to me at this place from philadelphia, has went round by the way of Cumberland and some of them came forward with a broken seal.

I hope you will please acquaint the port Master General of such Irregularities, in order that the defect may be remidied remedied . Captain Wade and Spark's companies have arrived here neither of them complet complete , I hope if no more is sent, these will be inadequate to the protection of our frontiers, and the defect ought to be Supplied by militia. more companies of Infantry and a troop of horses went on west the purpose, on which I have wrote the Secretary of war

closer.add: I have the honor to be & Signed

to each of He our Members in Congress
Letter to the members in Congress 7th January 1797
